separate.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Use separate knives for raw and cooked meat.
My wife and I have separate bank accounts.
separate.translation[0].definitions[1].d: not related to or not affected by something else
separate.translation[0].definitions[1].e: He was attacked on two separate occasions.
He tries to keep his professional life completely separate from his private life.
separate.translation[0].definitions[2].d: not joined to or touching something else
separate.translation[0].definitions[2].e: The gym and the sauna are in separate buildings.
Keep the fish separate from the other food.
separate.translation[1].definitions[0].d: if something separates two places or two things, it is between them so that they are not touching each other
separate.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The lighthouse is separated from the land by a wide channel.
separate.translation[1].definitions[1].d: to divide or split into different parts, or to make something do this
separate.translation[1].definitions[1].e: This will keep your dressing from separating.
First, separate the eggs (=divide the white part from the yellow part).
At this point, the satellite separates from its launcher.
Separate the students into four groups.
separate.translation[1].definitions[2].d: if two people who are married or have been living together separate, they start to live apart
separate.translation[1].definitions[2].e: Jill and John separated a year ago.
I decided to separate from my partner.
separate.translation[1].definitions[2].n: Separate is a reciprocal verb This type of verb is used when saying that two or more people or things do something that involves both or all of them
She and her husband separated from each other
separate.translation[1].definitions[3].d: to recognize that one thing or idea is different from another
separate.translation[1].definitions[3].e: She finds it difficult to separate fact from fantasy.
separate.translation[1].definitions[4].d: if people separate, or if someone or something separates them, they move apart
separate.translation[1].definitions[4].e: Ed stepped in to separate the two dogs.
In the fog, they got separated from the group.
separate.translation[1].definitions[5].d: to be the quality or fact that makes someone or something different from other people or things
separate.translation[1].definitions[5].e: The capacity to think separates humans from animals.
separate.translation[1].definitions[6].d: if an amount separates two things, one thing is better or older than the other by that amount
separate.translation[1].definitions[6].e: Three points now separate the two teams.
separate.translation[1].note_box[0].sect: to make something separate
separate
to divide something into two or more parts or groups, or to divide one type of thing from another. You use separate especially when saying that the parts are different from each other
Motorola is planning to separate the company into two public companies.
The items are separated into recyclable and non-recyclable waste.
divide
to make something become two or more parts or groups
The teacher divided us into groups.
The money was divided between them.
The house is divided into three apartments.
to separate something into two or more groups, parts etc – used especially when each part is equal in size
The class was split into groups of six.
break something up
to separate something into several smaller parts, especially to make it easier to deal with
The phone company was broken up to encourage competition.
Police used tear gas to break up the crowd.
segregate
to separate one group of people from others because of race, sex, religion etc
Schools were racially segregated.
Some prisons segregate prisoners who are infected with HIV.
to become separate
separate
to divide into different parts, especially in a natural way
A watery liquid separates from the milk during cheesemaking.
to separate into two or more parts or groups – used especially when each part is equal in size
What happens when an atom splits?
break up
to separate into several smaller parts
In spring, the icebergs begin to break up.
separate.translation[2].definitions[0].d: things that are separate are not connected or related to each other in any way
separate.translation[2].definitions[0].e: The finance team left to start aseparate company.
Many advertisers are running ads for two or more separate products.
separate.translation[2].definitions[1].d: if something is sent under separate cover, it is sent through the post in a different envelope from other documents
separate.translation[2].definitions[1].e: The information you requested is being sent under separate cover.
separate.translation[3].definitions[0].d: to divide something into two or more parts, or to cause something to be divided into two parts
separate.translation[3].definitions[0].e: The decision toseparate the business reflects the management’s current marketing strategy.
Rising competition separates the strong from the weak.
